properties.title: Gnadenthal
properties.note: Startingpoint of C. I. Latrobes easternmost Excursion throughout the Cape Colony of 1816 nearly to the borders of former so called Kaffraria. Latrobe was acompanied by the missionaries John Melville, John Henry Schmitt, Alice Schmitt, John JÃ¼rgen Stein, as well as the Khoikhoi Marcus Moses, Christian Hector, Jeremias Waly, Lebrecht Aris, Johannes Paerl and his father Leonhard Paerl.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 117
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/116/mode/2up

properties.title: Mr. Von Helsland's farm on Bock Revier
properties.note: The first stopp was made on a local farm of a Mister Von Helsland on the Bock River. The farm's position is not described any further, therefore the position is more of a guess than a secured information, since the farm is not existing anymore today.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 120
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/120/mode/2up

properties.title: Storm's Valley
properties.note: The travellers stopp at this place to rest in their tents, to avoid the sun. Latrobe describes this place as near the banks of the Sonderend, without a tree to screen us by its shade from the burning rays of the sun. They therefore call it the Hot Outspann. Today, the place is calles .
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 123
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/122/mode/2up

properties.title: Union of River Sonderend and Breede Revier
properties.note: The Travellers rested at the Banks of the River Sonderend on a wasteland called Storms Valley, from which they could see the place where River Sonderend united with Breede Revier. The exact place can not be determined anymore.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 124
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/124/mode/2up

properties.title: Banks of the Breede Revier
properties.note: Latrobe and his traveller party forded the Breede Revier and restet the night of March 7th 1816 on the eastern Banks of the River.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 124
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/124/mode/2up

properties.title: Leuwe Revier
properties.note: The Travellers forded the Leuwe Revier (Leeurivier) near a farm. An exact position can not be determined since there are no further descriptions.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 124
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/124/mode/2up

properties.title: Zwellendam
properties.note: Latrobe reached the settlement of Zwellendam (today written Swellendam) about 2 p.m. in the afternoon, where they stayed at the landdrost Mr. Von Buissini's house. The marker therefore is set on the drosty house which by today is a museum.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 124 ff.
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/124/mode/2up

properties.title: Bueffeljagd's Revier
properties.note: The Group fords the River today called Buffeljagsrivier after leaving Zwellendam to the east. The exact position was not described, therefore the marker remains less certain.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 128
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/128/mode/2up

properties.title: Zuurbrack
properties.note: The Mission Station of the London Missionary Society formed a settlement today calles Suurbaak. Latrobe and his travellers stayed there for only a few hours before continuing their journey.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 128
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/128/mode/2up

properties.title: Groot Vader's Bosch
properties.note: The vast forest at the foot of the Langeberg Mountain is today a protected area called Grootvadersbosch Nature Reserve.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 131
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/130/mode/2up

properties.title: Tygerfonteyn
properties.note: The Travellers stayed at Cornelius Snymans farm called Tygerfonteyn. The exact position is more of an estimation based on historical maps and therefore needs to be called very uncertain.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 135
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/134/mode/2up

properties.title: Stinkrevier
properties.note: The farm called Stinkrevier was another halt on the travellers way to Mosselbay. The position is an estimation based on historical maps.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 124
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/124/mode/2up

properties.title: Kleinberg
properties.note: Latrobe and his passed the Kleinfarm of a Mister Muller and resupplied. Today there is still a farm called Kleinberg, unfortunately there are no records proofing that it is located at the very same place as the 19th century farm. Therefore this position is more of an estimation.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 137
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/136/mode/2up

properties.title: Mossel-Bay
properties.note: Latrobe reached this place and the travel groupe stayed only for a few hours, before continuing their journey.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 138 ff.
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/138/mode/2up

properties.title: Hartenbosch
properties.note: At Hartenbosch (Hartenbos) Latrobe and his compagnions stayed one night. Today the former farm is a small seaside town.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 139 f.
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/139/mode/2up

properties.title: Great Brak Revier
properties.note: Latrobe describes at the further route, that after they forded the Little Sout Revier in two places, they halted on the banks of the great Brak Revier. The River today called Groot-brakrivier is enclosed by steep hills on each side. Fording is very likely on the place where today the citiy of Groot Brakrivier lies.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 141
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/140/mode/2up

properties.title: Hoogtekraal
properties.note: Latrobe visited Hoogtekraal to see the Reverend Pacalt of the London Missionary Society. After his death 1818 the settlement was renamend Pacaltsdorp.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 143
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/142/mode/2up

properties.title: George
properties.note: As one of the bigger settlements George was seat of the landdrost who invited Latrobe and his compagnons to stay two days. They used the time to resupply and to get new oxen to proceed further.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 145
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/144/mode/2up

properties.title: Kayman's Gat
properties.note: Latrobe describes this place as a beautiful glen which is very hard to pass. He writes of the Zwart Revier (Swartrivier) joining the glen too, which makes this point the most likely fording place of the travellers.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 150 ff.
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/150/mode/2up

properties.title: Trekata'kou
properties.note: Latrobe describes Trekata'kou or the Maidens Ford as a steep defile, similar to Kayman's Gat. The point is marked in historical maps but can't be located beyond a guess.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 152
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/152/mode/2up

properties.title: Melkhout Kraal
properties.note: Latrobe and the missionairs reach the farm Melkhout Kraal on the eastern shore of th Knysna Revier, which is by today the town of Knysna. The farm belonged to a Mr. George Rex, an english entrepreneur.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 158
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/158/mode/2up

properties.title: Jackal's Kraal
properties.note: Latrobe and his fellows visited Jackal's Kraal - at that time an empty vale - as a potential place for a third settlement. The place is described in detail, but with a strong focus to the environement and to as if it would have been a suitable place for a new settlement. An exact position is not mentioned. The location is therefore estimated upon historical maps and today only a road called Jackalskraal Road reminds of the former Name of the vale.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 161 f.
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/160/mode/2up

properties.title: Wittedrift
properties.note: Latrobes travel party forded the Wittedrift, which is described as a brook running into the Kierbooms Revier. Today, there is still a small settlement called Wittedrift. Unfortunately it is situated at the union of several small brooks, therefore the exact position is more of an estimation.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 168.
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/168/mode/2up

properties.title: Paerdekop
properties.note: The summit of the Paerdekop or Horse Head, as Latrobe translated it, had to be crossed by the travellers. He describes it as steep to all sides. Allthough searched for on historical cards, the exact position is hardly determined correctly due to the inaccuracy inherit to historical maps.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 170
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/170/mode/2up

properties.title: Welgelegen
properties.note: This farm was passed by the travellers on their way through the Lange Kloof. A huge valley reaching all the way from Avontuur to Kareedouw. Since there are no remains of the former farm, the position was estimated, using historical maps.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 178
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/178/mode/2up

properties.title: Ungelegen
properties.note: This former farm was visited by Latrobe's travel party on their way to KliphÃ¼bel, the veldcornet's place. Today remains a small settlement called Ongelegen at the place.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 179
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/178/mode/2up

properties.title: KliphÃ¼bel
properties.note: The former farm of the veldcornet Stephen Fereira. The Travellers stayed there for some conversation with the veldcornet and his family and for changing their oxen. The exact place of the Farm can only be roughly estimated using historical maps.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 179
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/178/mode/2up

properties.title: Ellandsfonteyn
properties.note: Latrobe and two of his travelling compagnions - Brother and Sister Schmitt - visited Mr. Piet Fereira's farm Ellandsfonteyn to receive new oxen for their ongoing journey through the cape colony. Today there are no remains of the farm, therefore the position was estimated upon historical maps.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 185
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/184/mode/2up

properties.title: Mr. Mey's Farm
properties.note: The travellers halted at the farmland belonging to Mr. Mey, both on their outbound and return routes. On their outbound here the party splitted to visit Mr. Mey and the farm Ellandsfonteyn in the close surrounding to get new oxen to proceed further. On the return they tried the same but could not get any new oxen. Comparing Latrobes map and a historical map of the same year, it shows that the farm has been called Miegunst. A small settlement of nearly the same name (Misgund) remains until today.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 185 (Description of the return route on Page 247 f.)
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/184/mode/2up

properties.title: Jagerbosch
properties.note: Latrobe's party reached the farm Jagerbosch of a german settler, called Mr. Akkerman, where they stayed for a night and received new oxen for their journey. Today, only a trainstations name reminds of the former farm.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 186
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/186/mode/2up

properties.title: Essenbosch
properties.note: The Travellers passed the farm and took a longer break in a valley nearby. Today, the exact positon can only be estimated upon historical maps.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 188
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/188/mode/2up

properties.title: Chamtoos Revier
properties.note: The travel party forded the River today called Gamtoosrivier at it's union with Kleinrivier where there has been a farm. The position is an estimation.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 196
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/196/mode/2up

properties.title: Van Staades Revier
properties.note: Before reaching the Van Staades Revier or Van Stadensrivier, as it is called today, Latrobe and his fellows visited two farms - Klaarefonteyn and Kaffre Kraal - of two Brothers Neukirch. Both farms are marked in the map attached to Latrobe's journal but are not to determine on a recent map, since the rivers depickted are traced very poorly or have changed their course drastically since 1816. Thus not beeing able to determine, where the travellers might have been, it is nearly impossible to estimated the exact point, where they forded the Van Staades Revier. The only hint givin is suggesting it must have been south of the mountain range since the party was able to see the indian ocean for a very short periode of time.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 202
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/202/mode/2up

properties.title: Uitenhagen
properties.note: Latrobe and his fellows reached the settlement and its drosty and stayed there where they met the landdrost, who helped them with their furtehr journey, but could not house them, since their group was too large. The former Drosty still exists and houses the Drosty Museum of Uitenhage, as the city is called today.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 203
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/202/mode/2up

properties.title: Bethelsdorp
properties.note: here
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 203
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/202/mode/2up

properties.title: Uitenhagen
properties.note: Latrobe and his fellows reached the settlement and its drosty on their outbound as well as on their return route. They met the landdrost Colonel Cuyler, who helped them with their furtehr journey, Mr. Allen, the secretary of the Governer at Cape Town and a german Gentleman Mr. Von Buchenrode who supported the groupe by providing meals and supplies on both visits. The former Drosty still exists and houses the Drosty Museum of Uitenhage or Kariega, as the city is called today. (Descriptions of the retourn bound are found on page 239)
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 203
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/202/mode/2up

properties.title: Geelhoutboom
properties.note: The place called Geelhoutboom was an resting place for the travelling party. The name can be translated to yellowwood tree and is very likely to describe the main species of trees found in the area. Unfortunately no further marks were errected that could have remained until today, so the position is estimated upon historical maps as the one attached to the journal.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 214
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/214/mode/2up

properties.title: Zondag's Revier and Witte Revier Union
properties.note: Latrobe visited the area with Mr. Melville, Brother Schmitt, the Khoikhoi Old Paerl and an unknown Khoikhoi soldier. They examined the former farmland to wether it would be fitting for the third moravian settlement. The landdrost of Uitenhagen, Coloney Cuely insistet in them having a look at it, although the party was rather sure, it would not be their place, since it was already occupied by a farmer called Mr. Scheper.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 215
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/214/mode/2up

properties.title: Witte Revier Valley
properties.note: Latrobe and his fellows examined this place to a large extend and talked to the owner Mr. Scheper about it beeing a suitable place for a moravian settlement. Although first approached with some reluctance due to it already beeing inhabitated, Latrobe soon found out, that the farmer was rather willing to leave it to the Moravians, since it was frequently encountered by Xhosa (called Caffres in the Journal) and wild animals, mostly elefants who did a lot of damage and prevented the farm from thriving. Latrobes group not yet announced it to be the third settlement, but the extend of his descriptions hints already its futur meaning as Witterivier or later Enon.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Pages 215-220
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/214/mode/2up

properties.title: Slagboom
properties.note: On there way from the Witte Revier to Kourney, Latrobe's party passed a place called Slagboom, a remaining name from the kaffre wars. Today, the name of a dam at the Witrivier reminds of the position.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 220
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/220/mode/2up

properties.title: Zuurberg
properties.note: Latrobe's travel party passes the steep mountain today called Suurberg slowly and very carefully, while their oxen are barrely convicable to pass the Mountain. It takes so much time, the party has to stay on a barren and dry place over night and is not ablle to reach the next point the same day.Since the Suurberg is a mountain range, the exact position of the passing is an estimation.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 222
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/222/mode/2up

properties.title: Military Post at Great Fish River
properties.note: After passing the farm of a Mr. Engelbrecht, the burning remains of another farm and an abandond former military post, the travellers finally reach the military post at the banks of Great Fish River, at that time commanded by Lieutenant Forbes. They stayed there to restock. The post did not remain until today but was marked at Latrobe's map as laying in the fork of Small and Great Fish River. Therefore a decent estimation of the position could be made.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 225
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/224/mode/2up

properties.title: Somerset Farm
properties.note: After an additional Night in the Banks of the Small Fish River, the Travellers reached Dr. Mackrill's Somerset Farm at foot of Boschberg. At the very same place today the Settlement Somerset East is found, that was founded around 1825.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 228
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/228/mode/2up

properties.title: Mr. P.'s Farm
properties.note: Latrobes Party reached the last point on their travel into the cape colony at the Farm of a Mr. P. The landdrost asked them to have a look at the place, which they did. After examining the farm and talking to the farmer himselfe they decided, to having been traveled far enough and therefore not to proceed any further. Also all other places further to be investigated and proposed by the landdrost of Uitenhagen where either occupied or in Caffraria (Xhosa-Land) and therefore not inhabitable with Khoikhoi-Settlements. This last farm is only described as an hour away from Somerset Farm, following the mountain range and fording the Small Fish River twice. Therefore the position is more of an estimation.
wasDerivedFrom: Journal of a Visit to South Africa, in 1815, and 1816. with some Account of the missionary Settlements of the United Bretheren, near the Cape of Good Hope. - Page 231
https://archive.org/details/journalofvisitto00latr/page/230/mode/2up
